name: 施欣文
objective:
本課程旨在介紹應用語言學 / 文學文化各領域重要議題與研究趨勢，以提供研究生在準備寫作研究論文時研究方向討論及導引。
This course introduces the main sub-disciplines, key issues and research trends in Applied Linguistics/Literature and Culture. It aims to provide graduate students with the fundamental knowledge and guidance needed for preparing and writing a research paper.

Students will come to my office to discuss matters related to researching and preparing and MA thesis, including the Taipei Tech library databases, library cataloging systems (Dewey Decimal and Library of Congress), NTU Library resources, Metacat (searching all the university libraries in Taiwan), and the resources and links for students on my website. We will discuss the general timeline for the proposal and thesis submission. We also will discuss plagiarism and patchwriting (https://britamericanlit.wordpress.com/plagiarism-and-patchwriting/) and do a self-quiz on both.
schedule: Four groups of students will meet with me once. They will meet with other professors on other weeks.
scorePolicy:
Students who are attentive throughout the session and ask good questions will receive between an 88–92 for our meeting. Students who have obviously prepared in advance may receive a higher grade, and students who seem less prepared or who are unable to hold a discussion with me and ask questions may receive a lower grade.

All students must also complete a short proposal, following the stipulated guidelines, which one of the professors will grade. Students should be especially careful to cite their sources correctly and to avoid patchwriting and plagiarism.
materials: Materials for the class are available on my MS Teams Guided Research Team. Students who do not have access to this team should e-mail me at <sharinschroeder@mail.ntut.edu.tw>. Students can also access many materials from my webpage for this class: https://britamericanlit.wordpress.com/guided-research-ma-and-ema-students/

name: 黃如瑩
objective: The purpose of this course is to guide our graduate students to explore their interested field, to look for possible critical approaches, to locate intriguing issues, to map out the various aspects pertaining to the discussions on certain topic, and to work out an inchoate proposal for the future MA thesis. In the end of the course, every student should hand in a tentative proposal for the possible MA thesis.
schedule:
Unit One: Using research resources

Unit Two: Searching for target field

Unit Three: Choosing a topic from the main text

Unit Four: Exploring applicable critical approaches

Unit Five: Working on an outline for the research

Unit Six: Writing the draft for the proposal of MA thesis
scorePolicy:
1. Participation in group meeting:80%
2. Final project: research outcome and chosen topic for the thesis 20%
materials:
1. Writing Research Papers:  A Norton Guide. 4th Edition. By Melissa Walker. new York: Norton. 1997.
2. Handbooks on MLA and APA Writing Styles.
